verses.text: O LORD, who may dwell in your tent? Who may live on your holy mountain?
verses.comment: This verse addresses God's presence and hints at the holiness required to be in God's sanctuary. 'Tent' refers to the tabernacle, the place of God's dwelling among His people. The 'holy mountain' symbolizes intimate communion with Godâ€”a theme fulfilled in Christ and the New Testament Church as the temple of the Holy Spirit (see 1 Cor. 3:16).

verses.text: He who walks blamelessly, does what is right, and speaks the truth from his heart,
verses.comment: This verse describes the moral integrity expected of those who seek God's presence. 'Blamelessness' often points to sincere devotion beyond outward actions. For Christians, Christ alone fulfills perfect righteousness, inviting us into a transformative relationship that enables us to share in His holiness (Heb. 12:14), best experienced through full participation in the Church's sacramental life.

verses.text: who does not slander with his tongue, does no evil to his neighbor, and does not bring shame upon his friend;
verses.comment: Guarding our words and protecting others from harm are central to living a godly life. This echoes God's command to love your neighbor (Matt. 22:39) and to practice genuine charity, a true sign of discipleship and unity in the faith.

verses.text: in whose eyes a vile person is rejected, but who honors those who fear the LORD; who keeps an oath even when it hurts, and does not change their word;
verses.comment: Upholding virtue, keeping one's word, and honoring the faithful reflect a higher standard of discipleship. This self-sacrificial fidelity points toward Christ, who fulfills the Law perfectly and invites believers to imitate Him within the fellowship of His people. Commitment and faithfulness, especially in sacred promises, build up not only individuals but the visible Body of Christ.

verses.text: who does not lend out his money at interest or take a bribe against the innocent. Whoever does these things will never be shaken.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes social justice and integrity, which reflect God's own character. The prohibition against usury and bribes shows that faithfulness is holistic, touching on economic and social life as an expression of genuine faith. Those rooted in truth and charity stand firm forever, prefiguring those who will inherit God's Kingdom (Matt. 25:34).
